Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the model - (R, A): Average 1 hour, STDEV 10 minutes -> seems reasonable. - (R, E): Average 1 day, STDEV 8 hours -> reasonable. - (R, P): Average ~25 hours (90000 seconds = 25 hours), STDEV 1 hour -> very low STDEV, meaning almost exactly 25 hours every time. This is suspicious.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: We are also given that the process steps are: R, A, E, P, N, C. So we expect the path to be R -> A -> E -> P -> N -> C. (A, C): Average 2 hours, which is quick, and note that there is no E or P in between. This might indicate that claims are closed immediately after assignment without going through evaluation and approval.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The anomalies we are to identify are from the provided model. a. (R, P): Very low STDEV (1 hour) for a 25-hour average. This suggests a very consistent time, which might be artificial. b. (P, N): Very long average (7 days) and high STDEV (2 days), indicating inconsistent and long delays. c. (A, C): Average 2 hours quick. d. (E, N): Very quick (5 minutes) with low STDEV (1 minute).

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: For (R, P): Low STDEV might be due to an automated process that runs at fixed intervals or a rule that sets the approval date to exactly 25 hours after receipt. For (P, N): The long and variable delay might be due to manual notification process or backlog. For (A, C): The quick closure might be due to auto-closure rules or adjuster shortcuts. For (E, N): The quick notification might be due to an automated notification system.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Propose verification queries using SQL on claim_events table to identify claims where time between activities falls outside expected ranges based on AVG and STDEV. For each anomaly design queries like finding claims where time diff deviates significantly correlate with claim_type resource adjuster.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Now we are to present: 1. Anomalies list the four. 2. Hypotheses give possible reasons for each. 3. Verification queries provide at least one query for each anomaly.
